Modal

  • Usage guidelines
  • Basic modal
  • Image cap

Usage Guidelines

A Modal is a secondary window that appears on top of the main UI and must be dismissed or engaged before it allows the user to return to the main UI. Modals are primarily meant as very brief interludes in the user experience to either present featured content or offer up a targeted interaction to get work done within the scope of the main task or activity.

Do

  • Use to direct the user to featured content
  • Use to direct the user's attention to a sub-task without taking them away from the current screen

Don't

  • Use for extended activities or tasks
  • Use to show alerts, error, success, or warning messages
  • Use on mobile devices
  • Use for multi-step processes
  • Make content scroll within the modal window

Basic modal

Modals should be triggered by some user action. Buttons are the most common way to trigger a modal, as shown in this example.

Say hello to Apollo

Cras mattis consectetur purus sit amet fermentum. Etiam porta sem malesuada magna mollis euismod. Aenean lacinia bibendum nulla sed consectetur.

Image cap

Adding an image cap to a modal is simple. Just place the image before the .modal-header and use the .img-fluid utility to make it scale to fit the available space.

Say hello to Apollo

Cras mattis consectetur purus sit amet fermentum. Etiam porta sem malesuada magna mollis euismod. Aenean lacinia bibendum nulla sed consectetur.
